title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from Iraq engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Iraq?
preds: Changing forecast due to increase in activity in Iraq. Political changes may increase threat to civilians due to religious infighting.

The current civilian death toll for all incidents in Iraq stands at 463 for the period of April to May 2018, according to the Iraq Body Count database. The death toll is down significantly from years past, but thus far, there have been an average of 289 civilian deaths per month in 2018. Extrapolating this out for the next 12 months gives a total of 3,468. As conventional fighting has died down since the liberation of Mosul, many of these casualties can be attributed to be the result of deliberate targeting (in the form of terrorism).  https://www.iraqbodycount.org/database/
Hard to tell if the students protest get to loud could happen at any time.
No it takes a lot of fire power to kill 1,000 people and planning
The region is unstable enough that there is a chance that some troubles happen, but specifically the systematic killing of 1000 civilians seems low.

At the moment, things seem relatively stable and the central government seems to be consolidating its power. The systematic killing of civilians probably wont happen unless there is a major uprising threatening the stability, legitimacy, and authority of the central government. Typically, its been Iraqi Kurds, however, I don’t see the Kurds attempting to challenge Baghdad this time around.

Updating my forecast based on newly discovered data. 1) According to Iraq Body Count, there have already been 1,589 civilian deaths since January. Although the nature of these events and the groups involved are hard to discern, it's highly likely the overall death toll that qualifies for the resolution of this question will exceed 1000. 2) In addition to the above, ACLED reports that the primary actor involved in these events is IS. 2) The May 12th elections are likely to be a flashpoint and a target for IS terrorism

The Sunni's have been pretty thoroughly beat down. 
Saudi Arabia in the midst of power transition is dealing with issues in Yemen and Syria.  I don't believe it will have the stomach to fund in Iraq in the immediate future.
There's a small possibility daesh or some other group working in tandem might catapult a crisis

Iraq is in a consolidation phase.  This does not preclude the probability of future conflict outbreaks.  Rather, groups are consolidating their gains, Sunnis are beat down, and Kurdish factions are unlikely to test Baghdad again this year.  Furthermore, the number of countries with over 1,000 civilians are killed in a year is not that high.

It is relatively stable there now. Unless something very serious occurs, either religiously or politically, a systematically induced killing of civilians probably won't happen within the suggested timeframe.
Iran will be too busy in Syria moving against Kurds.
I find this whole array of questions racist and western-centric.  Why is the same question not posed about any western countries?

surprised at 20% consensus...but maybe I’m missing something?
